Posts.Title: Pet Scan Verbiage Question screech screech

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2016 05:56AM - edited Apr 20, 2016 05:57AM by screech It was in a section called Findings. The exact wording is: Reference background liver activity is 3.2 As for the rest of the report: Nothing found in head and neck, nothing found in chest, nothing found in abdomen and pelvis, and nothing fund in musculoskeletal except a thing they feel is a injection granuloma located pretty much where they give me a trelstar shot quarterly-that referenced seeing it in previous scans. At the bottom of the report in the Impressions section it says: No evidence of recurrent or metastatic breast cancer. I really, truly appreciate everyone chiming in. Thank you. I have been NED from completion of treatment-knock wood of course

Posts.Title: so thankful I found this site!! Allyme Allyme

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2015 06:53PM - edited Mar 9, 2015 07:00PM by screech same for me. I have always been extremely healthy, fairly athletic, non smoker, light social drinks...that being said I think that health enabled me to ruise through 12 x taxol, 4 x AC, a double mx, and 28 radiation to the breast. I didn't miss any time for the chemo from work other than the appointments, no time for radiation (although I did have a lot of fatigue). I only missed seven days for my operation. I also rode my bike like crazy, went camping, swimming, etc. Now I go monthly for a Zometa infusion and take a daily Aromasin. I will be scanned at the end of this month to see what might be still hot. What has your treatment been? Feel free to PM me-I try to remember to check that.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2014 10:25AM screech wrote: Hi Banderso:  Let me tell you my tale.  I was originally thought to be a stage 3 but a spot in my sacral they didn't think was cancer is completely gone after the chemo for stage 3.  Due to the response they feel it is/was a met.  It was in a very difficult place to biopsy so that was not done.  I have had (in this order) 12 rounds of taxol, 4 rounds of A/C,  a double mx with expanders placed and 28 rounds of radiation to clean out the localized cancer.  I am currently getting a monthly infusion of Zometa (bisphosphonate mentioned by Heidihill) and daily Aromasin.  It sounds like a lot, but it really hasn't been too bad and I have virtually no SE from the Zometa/Aromasin.    I've worked full time (didn't even miss a full day during chemo-would get treatment in the morning and then continue onto work for the rest of the day and for the mx-I only missed seven days of work, radiation was so quick and first thing in the morning so I wasn't even late getting into my office), kept physically active, etc the whole time.  I'm actually at a point now where I only have an appointment or two a month!  It's been a long time from last March but it wasn't all bad.  The radiation was probably the hardest on me-wore me out completely but that was just a matter of being really tired by the last week or so of it.    The mind game of will I be clean (remission/ned whatever you want to call it) in the scan they will do coming up in late Feb/March is the toughest part. That being said, because it appears to be only in the bones and appears to have responded well to treatment they say there is a LOT of hope for me, and I would assume the same for you, as far as longevity and quality of life.  Not to mention, some of my doctors truly feel that we are right around the corner from turning this into a TRUE chronic disease and that I just need to stay on treatment and keep healthy (exercise, diet, etc).  I hope they are right!   Heidihill-you and many others here that have been in treatment for years (and counting!) are keeping me sane!

Posts.Content: screech wrote: I posted this in the stage 4 forum, but I was wondering if anyone that uses the stage 3 forum could comment?  Thank you. I am wondering if I am in complete denial, or if I am just optimistically hopeful.  I was diagnosed a year ago in March with BC-bilateral, one side they said probably stage 0, one probably a 3.  They did a PET which showed one tiny hot spot in the sacral region.  It was unable to be biopsied so it went unconfirmed.  Then did AC/T and was re-scanned.  PET showed complete response-no sign of where the spot was.  Just showed as healed/filled in.  Because of response they say it was a metastasis.  Then had a BMX (showing clean lymph nodes), then radiation.  Started on Zometa/Aromasin.  Had another PET at the end of March-NED!  Do you think it is impossible that this spot was not a metastasis?  Does anyone else have similar experiences?  Thank you. Dx 3/2014, Stage IIIB, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 3/26/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 6/11/2014 AC Dx 8/2014, Stage IV, 0/2 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2- Surgery 9/3/2014 Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Hormonal Therapy 9/24/2014 Aromasin (exemestane) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 17, 2015 12:38PM screech wrote: ElaineTherese-I think sometimes you get Zometa with Aromasin regardless.  I think it depends on the condition of your bones - osteoporosis, etc. but I don't think it would be monthly like I am.  I will go to quarterly at some point if all remains well. With the spot they saw on my first pet-the reason they said it was most likely a met is because it had a complete response to chemo-it's gone.  Had it still been there they wouldn't have worried about it. Thank you for responding!

Posts.Title: hope or denial? screech screech

Posts.Content: May 15, 2015 04:24AM screech wrote: Allyme, I have/had an Unconfirmed met to my sacral.  It showed hot on a PET, but two of three radiologists said they didn't think it was cancerous.  It was in a spot that couldn't be biopsied.  Fast forward past 12x taxol and 4 x AC - had another PET and it was completely gone.  Because of that they say it was a met - not 100%, but very, very probable.  I then had a double mx and 28 x radiation.  Just last week got my permanent implants.  That being said, I continued will ALL treatments (Aromasin and Zometa).  I figure if by some very SLIM chance the spot was not cancerous that I will have been aggressive as possible.  If  (and it probably is) it is a met - then I am doing all the treatments recommended.  Stay strong!
